Endoscopic Endonasal Approach to the Mid.action_description: The sphenoid sinus is widely opened.
The palato-sphenoid artery is identified and disconnected.
The Antero-lateral Triangle is exposed by drilling.
The Lingual Process is located and identified
The Foramen Ovale is located and identified
Dura Mater opened and closed using fat graft and septal flap.

Large Third Ventricular Tumors_ Transcal.action_description: Linear skin incision, typically on the right side, centered on the coronal suture or two-thirds anterior and one-third posterior to it.
A relatively small craniotomy (approximately 5-6 cm in the anterior-to-posterior direction) is created, often centered over the coronal suture.
The dura is opened in a curvilinear fashion, based along the superior sagittal sinus.
The interhemispheric fissure is dissected to expose the corpus callosum.
A relatively small callosotomy (approximately 2cm) is performed, just to the right of the midline, to expose the ipsilateral lateral ventricle.
The ipsilateral lateral ventricle is entered for CSF release.
The septal vein is transected at its junction with the thalamostriate vein to expand the Foramen of Monro.
The Foramen of Monro is expanded by transecting the septal vein and performing a minimal anterior transchoroidal dissection.
The tumor within the third ventricle is exposed and resected.

Peri-atrial GBM_ Transfalcine Approach_7.action_description: A linear incision is made just posterior to the parietal bossing.
A craniotomy is performed exposing the width of the superior sagittal sinus.
The dura is opened, preserving the parasagittal veins. These veins are untethered to increase the working zone.

A "T" shaped incision is made in the falx cerebri to expose the contralateral medial hemisphere (precuneus). The inferior sagittal sinus is coagulated and transected. If the vertical incision approaches the straight sinus, it is angled obliquely posterior to anterior.
A corticotomy is performed through the precuneus to access the contralateral atrium.

Petrous Apex Meningioma_ Transtentorial.comments: Although the narrator mentions the 4th cranial nerve, it's not clearly shown being manipulated.  The tentorium is clearly shown.
The video covers the removal of both the pre- and post-tentorial portions of the mass from the same incision, hence the long time period here

Resection of Foramen Magnum Meningioma v.action_description: The muscles overlying the occipital bone and C1/C2 laminae were mobilized in the subperiosteal plane and the myocutaneous flap was reflected inferolaterally.

The vertebral artery was identified in the sulcus arteriosus on the superior surface of C1 and carefully dissected free from surrounding ligaments to allow lateral mobilization during dural reflection.
A lateral suboccipital craniectomy and C1 hemilaminectomy were performed. This involved removing the lateral suboccipital bone and a portion of the C1 lamina.
Partial resection of the occipital condyle (<30%) was performed. The posterior cortex of the condyle was drilled, following the posterior condylar vein as a landmark.
A curvilinear dural incision was made, taking care to avoid intradural neurovascular structures, including the vertebral artery and its branches, and the spinal accessory nerve.

Transfalcine Route for Preservation of P.action_description: A linear incision is made just posterior to the parietal bossing.
A craniotomy is performed exposing the width of the superior sagittal sinus.
The dura is opened, preserving the parasagittal veins. These veins are untethered to increase the working zone.

A “T” shaped incision is made in the falx cerebri to expose the contralateral medial hemisphere (precuneus). The inferior sagittal sinus is coagulated and transected. If the vertical incision approaches the straight sinus, it is angled obliquely posterior to anterior.
A corticotomy is performed through the precuneus to access the contralateral atrium.
